column1: After his return from the Creek War
column2: he was elected to Congress in 1826 and in 1828. He was defeated in 1830 and re-elected in 1832. When he was first elected he knew very little about the government
column3: and was totally ignorant of his duties as a member of Congress
column4: but here again his good common sense and bright mind came to his aid; and although he worked under great disadvantages
column5: yet he won respect and admiration from the other law-makers. He was always a curious and noticeable figure in Washington
column6: both on account of his dress
column7: which was similar to that of his backwoods companions
column9: which was as strange as his clothes. Such a man could not help being noticed
column10: and on a trip which he made to Philadelphia
column12: he was received everywhere kindly and added not a little to his fame.
